results.title: Ben Green, Escaping the Impossibility of Fairness: From Formal to Substantive Algorithmic Fairness
results.snippet: First, I diagnose the problems of the current methodology for algorithmic fairness, which I call “formal algorithmic fairness.” Because formal algorithmic fairness restricts analysis to isolated decision-making procedures, it leads to the impossibility of fairness and to models that exacerbate oppression despite appearing “fair.” Second, I draw on theories of substantive equality from law and philosophy to propose an alternative methodology, which I call “substantive algorithmic fairness.” Because substantive algorithmic fairness takes a more expansive scope of analysis, it enables an escape from the impossibility of fairness and provides a rigorous guide for alleviating injustice with algorithms.

results.snippet: Using the PRISMA methodology, it synthesizes diverse strands of research to assess how bias is theorized, measured, and mitigated across disciplines. The findings reveal a persistent lack of consensus on how algorithmic bias and fairness should be defined, leading to challenges in both theoretical articulation and practical implementation.

results.title: Marta Ziosi, David Watson & Luciano Floridi, A Genealogical Approach to Algorithmic Bias
results.snippet: The Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency (FAccT) literature tends to focus on bias as a problem that requires ex post solutions (e.g. fairness metrics), rather than addressing the underlying social and technical conditions that (re)produce it. In this article, we propose a complementary strategy that uses genealogy as a constructive, epistemic critique to explain algorithmic bias in terms of the conditions that enable it.
